sourceDesc.p: This is the feature-file for PFV inflection: 3sg.f in iii w/y verbs.

revisionDesc.change: For EGY-___ there are no values found
updating references to Zotero IDs via update-bibl-refs.xsl

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Very old generation (70+) and some speakers from the old generation (60+) shows -at (e.g. nisat - she forgot) while middle aged and young speakers show generally -yit (e.g. nisyit - she forgot).
Very old generation (70+) and some speakers from the old generation (60+) shows -at (e.g. nisat - she forgot) while middle aged and young speakers show generally -yit (e.g. nisyit - she forgot).
both a and i type verbs have -at
both a and i type verbs have -at
both a and i type verbs have -at
both a and i type verbs have -at
only in Ḥāyil
only in Ḥāyil
the verb to forget had a qatala form (néset) in the dialects studied between 1934-35 (Cantineau 1937:197)
the verb to forget had a qatala form (néset) in the dialects studied between 1934-35 (Cantineau 1937:197)
both a and i type verbs have -at
Palva 1980:128 gives also nisat "she forgot" but he does not give further details on the use of the two forms
Talay (1999) differentiates between an a-type and an ə-type. This example is an a-type verb. The verb "to forget" can be conjugated in both ways: nasat and nəsyət.
Talay (1999) differentiates between an a-type and an ə-type. This example is an ə-type verb. The verb "to forget" can be conjugated in both ways: nasat and nəsyət.
Behnstedt (1997) differentiates between an a-type and an i-type. This example is an a-type verb.
Behnstedt (1997) differentiates between an a-type and an i-type. This example is an i-type verb.

Behnstedt (1994) divides defective verbs into three different types: (1) pure a-type, (2) pure i-type and (3) a mixed type. "laka" is an example for a pure a-type. He lists three examples for mixed types: raḏ̣̣a - irḏ̣̣i (to agree), ṛaga - irgi (to go up) and nasa - insi (to forget)

cit.quote: she became free, she is free

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Behnstedt (1994) divides defective verbs into three different types: (1) pure a-type, (2) pure i-type and (3) a mixed type. "ifḏ̣̣i" is an example for a pure i-type. He lists three examples for mixed types: raḏ̣̣a - irḏ̣̣i (to agree), ṛaga - irgi (to go up) and nasa - insi (to forget).
According to Wittrich (2001) the suffix turns into -at when verbs end with the long vowel ā: banā + -ət becomes banat

Löhr (1905) notes that there are two different patterns for defective verbs in the perfect: (1) fiʕil and (2) faʕal. The suffix for (1) in the 3. Person feminin singular is -at and for (2) -it (nisit - she forgot)

Löhr (1905) notes that there are two different patterns for defective verbs in the perfect: (1) fiʕil and (2) faʕal. The suffix for (1) in the 3. Person feminin singular is -at (karat - she rented out) and for (2) -it.
Behnstedt (1997) differentiates between an a-type and an i-type. This example is an a-type verb.
Behnstedt (1997) differentiates between an a-type and an i-type. This example is an i-type verb.
Behnstedt (1997) differentiates between an a-type and an i-type. In this dialect both types have the same ending (nisat).
Behnstedt (1997) differentiates between an a-type and an i-type. This example is an a-type verb.
Behnstedt (1997) differentiates between an a-type and an i-type. This example is an i-type verb.
Behnstedt (1997) differentiates between an a-type and an i-type. In this dialect both types have the same ending (nisat).
Behnstedt (1997) differentiates between an a-type and an i-type. This example is an a-type verb.
Behnstedt (1997) differentiates between an a-type and an i-type. This example is an i-type verb.
If a defective verbs ends with an -a, the vowel gets replaced by the verbal suffix -et.
If a defective verbs ends with an -i, the vowel is retained as y.

Leitner (2022) notes that the second vowel "a" of a verb with a final week root combines with the final root consonant and therefore the stem ends in "i" or "a". Verbs with a final root consonant ʔ have the same structure and always end with "a".

cit.quote: it is expensive, it became expensive

wib:featureValueObservation.note: The author notes that this dialect has an a-stem and an i-stem. The example provided here is an a-stem.
The author notes that this dialect has an a-stem and an i-stem. The example provided here is an i-stem.
Maltese orthography: mxiet
Johnstone (1967:50) states that this ending is typical of all eastern Arabian dialects, and is not specific for Bahrain. There is also no distinction between the ʕArab and the Baḥārna communities
Johnstone (1967:50) states that this ending is typical of all eastern Arabian dialects, and is not specific for Bahrain. There is also no distinction between the ʕArab and the Baḥārna communities
A particularity of the Baḥārna dialect is that, in the s-stem of verbs the /a/-type, the radical /y/ shows up in the 3rd person forms (Holes 2016:210)
Johnstone (1967:50) states that this ending is typical of all eastern Arabian dialects, and is not specific for Kuwait

Johnstone (1967:50) states that this ending is typical of all eastern Arabian dialects and is not specific for Qatar. Johnstone (1967:113) states that for Qatar there is a tendency for forms of the pattern fiʕil to occur, e.g. miši, but he does not give an example for the 3.P.Sg.F.
This verb follows the pattern C1aC2a (Johnstone 1988:90)
This verb follows the pattern C1aC2i, but before vocalic endings the stem is C1aC2y- (Johnstone 1988:91)
This verb follows the pattern C1VC2a (Johnstone 1988:90-91)
This verb follows the pattern C1iC2i, but before vocalic endings the stem is C1aC2y- (Johnstone 1988:91-92)
This verb follows the pattern C1aC2a (Johnstone 1988:90)
This verb follows the pattern C1iC2i, but before vocalic endings the stem is C1iC2iy- (Johnstone 1988:91)
This verb follows the pattern CiVC2a (Johnstone 1988:90-91)
This verb follows the pattern C1VC2e (Johnstone 1988:90-91)

Communis form, therefore, šaka can also be used for the feminine.
The ending -yet (-iet) is found in both CiCi and CCa stems (cf. Borg 1985:89)
